chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College but reduce winner-take-all by requiring states to allocate electors proportionally using a uniform, auditable method, with electors bound to the certified result. Pair that with national minimum standards for ballot access, chain-of-custody, post-election audits, and clear recount triggers so close outcomes are handled consistently across states. If the country still wants a stronger “majority winner” guarantee, states could adopt ranked-choice ballots for president while keeping the same state-based elector structure.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should focus on rules people can trust: keep the state-based Electoral College but end winner-take-all by requiring proportional (or district-based with anti-gerrymandering safeguards) allocation of electors nationwide and binding electors to the certified result. Pair that with clear national minimum standards for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and uniform recount triggers/timelines so close elections are transparent and consistent across states. If the country wants to go further later, add a majority check—ranked-choice ballots or an automatic runoff—to ensure the winner has broad national support while encouraging candidates to compete beyond a handful of battlegrounds.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A workable middle ground is to keep the Electoral College but end winner-take-all nationwide by allocating electors proportionally (with a clear, simple threshold) and requiring electors to be bound to the certified results. Pair that with bipartisan national minimum standards—paper-backed ballots, routine audits, clear recount triggers, and uniform certification timelines—so close elections are handled consistently no matter the state. If the country later wants a stronger majority mandate, add a ranked-choice ballot or automatic runoff option that preserves broad, cross-regional campaigning while reducing spoiler fears.
